misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the assignment as a distance calculator instead of a grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points rather than the requested grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0–100) and outputs a letter grade based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user, determine which letter grade range it falls into (A–F), and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade: "Enter x1 and y1:" and "Enter x2 and y2:"
Program never reads a single grade value
No conditional logic based on grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.)
Output is the numeric distance between two points, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment problems or reuse of a template for a distance-calculation task instead of reading the current problem requirements carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the program from the perspective of handling a single numeric grade. Start by reading one double or int value for the grade, then design if/else if/else conditions for the A–F ranges, and finally print the appropriate letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (input prompts, variables, calculations, and output) is about coordinates and distance, with no mention of grades or letter outputs, strongly indicating a complete mismatch with the assignment.

evidence.note: The entire main method is structured around reading two points and printing their distance, with no reference to grades, grade ranges, or letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (likely a previous assignment) instead of the required Grade Calculator (Q3). This means none of the requirements for Q3 have been met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the wrong file or code for Q3. They implemented the distance formula, not the grade calculation logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct program must read one numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance between points, not a letter grade.
Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
No conditional logic (if-else statements) present.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student misunderstands or overlooked the specific requirements for Question 3 and submitted irrelevant code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment description for Q3 and ensure you write a completely new program that addresses the letter grade conversion requirement.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the task (Grade Calculator) specified in Q3. It calculates the distance between two points, a completely different common programming problem.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates the distance between two points, not a letter grade, thus failing to meet any rubric requirements for Q3.

misconceptions.name: Solving the wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution to a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem requested in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not a grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges. The solution should use conditional statements (if/else) to check the grade ranges, not mathematical distance calculations.
symptoms: Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grades
Output displays distance value instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from a different assignment or misunderstood the problem statement entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The program should: (1) Read a single integer grade, (2) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculator) rather than the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.

evidence.note: Student is reading four coordinate values instead of a single grade value as required by Q3

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete program to compute the distance between two points using their coordinates, instead of implementing the required grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them using the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and then use conditional statements to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade value.
No conditional logic is present to check grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
The output is the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
The class name and comments reference distance between points, not grades.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have misread the assignment or reused a solution from a different problem (distance between two points) instead of implementing the requested grade calculator. This indicates a misunderstanding or lack of attention to the problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement and identify: (1) the required input (a single numeric grade 0-100), (2) the required output (a letter grade A-F), and (3) the decision logic (ranges for A, B, C, D, F). Discard the distance-formula code and write a new program that uses if/else-if/else statements to map the numeric grade to the correct letter.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using conditionals
Separating different programming tasks or exercises
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program, including variable names, prompts, comments, and computations, is devoted to calculating distance between two points; there is no reference to grades or letter outputs, so it clearly addresses a different problem than the one assigned.

evidence.note: All code focuses on reading coordinates and computing the distance between two points; there is no handling of a numeric grade or mapping to a letter grade as required by the assignment.

No logic for handling grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.)

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure the submitted code addresses the specified requirements (reading a numeric grade and using conditional statements to determine the letter grade).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is unambiguously for a different problem (distance calculation) and contains none of the elements required for the grade calculator problem (conditionals, grade input).

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of Assignment Requirements

misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they needed to write a program to calculate the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a grade

misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read the assignment specification or submitted the wrong solution file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q3 carefully. You need to: (1) read ONE numeric grade input, (2) use if-else statements to check grade ranges, (3) output the corresponding letter grade A/B/C/D/F.
